title: An Informal Ruth's Chris?
text:
On our anniversary trip to Asheville, we purposely packed our business casual clothes for our celebratory dinner at Ruth's Chris. Having dined in our local restaurant in the past, we were aware of the dress code and dared not go without dressing up a bit. We could have left those clothes at home as it was more of a come as you are restaurant; everything from suits (a few, not many) to shorts, jeans, mid-riff shirts, sneakers, etc. Doesn't impact the service we received (which was very good and nice to have our special occasion recognized) or the quality of the food. But again, the ambiance is a bit missing (including the valet staff, but hey I guess Asheville has a different vibe).

The petite fillets were done as ordered, sizzling in butter and a nice taste. The mash potato side was also tasty (enough to share). The only flop on the meal was the shoestring potatoes which were over cooked and overly crispy. But I ate them anyway.

Good bread and we appreciated the complimentary dessert (ice cream and a chocolate lava type cake; would have liked the apple crisp tart, but hey after spending $145 for the dinner not including tip, I won't complain on saving a few dollars).

title: Very good caramels
text: Stopped by and enjoyed the smells of this boutique chocolate store. Bought an assortment of caramels which I'm told are made on site. they were very good.

title: Grand Dame in Asheville
text:
Spent a nice midweek stay at this Grand Dame nestled above Asheville. This was our first visit and we were immediately taken with the view as you enter the property. It is imposing for sure. It is also a very busy property with people and cars coming and going. The front has a large porch area with rocking chairs so you can sit and enjoy the hustle and bustle.

The grand front lobby has plenty of sitting and plenty of people. You are immediate drawn to the back doors and the views from the back decks of the valley golf course and the waterfall in front of the Spa. It is a sight to behold. Note: the property is open to all so you'll see and hear a lot of tours being conducted for visitors.

Check in is at 4pm and I got the feel that early check in is not welcomed at all. You can call at the front desk, they will check you in however your room most likely won't be ready until 4. They will text you when you can come and pick up your key. That gives you some time to walk around and acquaint yourself with the shops and eateries, the sports complex, etc.

Our room was a standard room in the main lodge (room 555). True to our luck it was the room immediately by the elevator. On the plus side, the rooms re well insulated from the noise and other than the occasional loud guest and welcome/bye bye as people entered and departed the elevator (manned by an attendant, only two riders at a time), we heard very little noise.

The room is of good size, with a king bed, window overlooking the front of the lodge, four nice, soft pillows, plenty of storage (closet, built in draws, separate closet with ironing board, a good size bathroom, large TV with a very quiet mini-fridge in cabinet below, two armed chairs (a bit on the slender size for sitting) and desk. Two robes can be found in the closet (with a safe and key).

Bathroom had some signs of mold behind the sink faucets and the glass door to the tub/shower combo. The rubber molding for the shower glass opening was also coming off. Caution for those with some mobility issues, you may have trouble climbing into and out of the tub (it's deep and no real handles to steady yourself getting in and out). The shower had nice, constant pressure and an adjustable shower head. We were not able to redirect the water from shower to tub, so not sure if that was an issue with us or the facet. Had four nice and thick towels, a hair dryer and shampoo/soap/conditioner accessories.

We did not eat at the lodge (couldn't get reservations last minute). They offered us a free coffee from the marketplace but didn't use those coupons either.

Parking is at a premium if you self park (added charge per day). We ended up having to park near the sports complex and walk (hike) to up hill to the lodge each day. They do offer valet parking which takes most of the nearby spaces. Didn't appear they offered on property shuttle to the parking areas.

Overall was nice to spend our special anniversary occasion (not recognized in any way by the hotel) at the Lodge. I did use their onsite flower shop to order an arrangement which was delivered as promised.

title: Pandemic has taken its toll
text: Unfortunately the pandemic has appear to have taken its toll with many empty shop spaces. Those that were still open were nice but not like we recalled on our visit a few years ago. Interior was dark but it is conveniently located across the Wall St. parking garage.

title: Nice open setting
text: Unfortunately they were not doing glass blowing demonstrations when we visit but still they were working on a piece. The exhibit and shop has a nice variety of brightly colored glass items. Worth the walk from the downtown center.

title: Nice gallery. Free parking nearby
text: Was our second visit to the gallery while visiting Asheville. The gallery has a very nice collection and appeals to all tastes. The prices are very reasonable. We will cherish the pottery we found on this trip.

title: Those donuts are big
text:
Stopped by after reading some reviews in anticipation of some great donuts on our recent trip to Asheville. First impression was, wow those are some big donuts. We ordered two Vortex doughnuts (cinnamon sprinkled with a drizzle of chocolate) and one chocolate covered; a small (12oz) drip coffee and one hot chocolate (whole milk).

The pros: those are some big doughnuts and they looked good.

The cons: those big doughnuts has no taste whatsoever. The coffee was terrible (wife actually tossed hers out) and like the donuts the hot chocolate had very little taste to it.

Yeast based, these are light and chewy. I love chocolate but there was no taste to this these. Exceptionally disappointing.

Can't recommend.

title: A good option for lunch when you don't want to wait around too long for a table
text: it's a Mellow Mushroom and the food is predictable. The service was very good and it was nice to be able to get in with very little wait which is often not possible at other places in this very busy, foodie town.

title: Excellent Lunch
text: Pleasantly surprised when we stopped in for lunch. First the basket of fried pork rinds were fantastic and addictive. The service was attentive and pleasant. For lunch we ordered a seafood platter with shrimp and scallops panned fried. Excellent, moist and well seasoned. Fries were wonderful (coated and crunchy). The cocktail sauce was superb. Wife had the shrimp croissant sandwich which was also fantastic (maybe a bit too much onion but otherwise top notch).

title: Disappointing
text:
Attended here with a large party and unfortunately the food disappointed. The service did not and was top notch. Our server did an amazing job.

So the food. We started with their pretzel. It was ok, could have used a bit more salt and wasn't a big fan of the butter slathered on top (my fault, I should have asked for it not to be put on). For my main, I ordered the wurst sampler substituting another weisswurst for the garlic bratwurst. So it was two weisswurst, a knackwurst and double sauerkraut. I'm seldom disappointed with wurst and love weisswurst. This was by far some of the worse wurst I've had. The weisswurst were grilled, not boiled and were overcooked. The knackwurst was good. The sauerkraut was by far the worse I've ever had in a restaurant. It had little taste and what taste it had was almost inedible. Having lived in Germany and visited many times, I'm love my wurst and sauerkraut. This was not one of those good experiences. Wife had the chicken 'schnitzel' which was a good portion though more like a fried chicken cutlet than a schnitzel. Her red cabbage on the other hand was very good. For dessert, tried the strudel. It was fine.

title: Simply this place is dirty
text: Grabbed a quick bite to eat here and wish we hadn't. Sure the food is typical Wendy so no surprises. The facility itself was dirty. Every table in the place as not clean (we checked them trying to find one), the floor was filthy, and the trash receptacles were overflowing. Due to being busy? Nope, just one other table was occupied and the staff was just hanging around talking instead of cleaning. Stay away.

title: A little on the dated side in a very touristy town
text:
Definitely not the cheapest hotel in town in a very touristy town. Stayed two nights in the tower suite (room 333) as it looked to be a little bit out of the norm than normal rooms. Kind of a mix bag for the money so here are the pros/cons

Pros: at the top of the tower, there's no noise coming from the rooms below (good separation) and no one on your sides. Though the hotel does allow pets in some of their rooms and we had a large dog somewhere near us that barked occasionally.

The room is large enough with steps separating the living/kitchen area and the bed/bath.

Plenty of lights and plenty of windows.

Location is good, though be prepared the hotel is close to the several fest halls with one being just next door so you will hear the music from there until they shut down. There's also a lot of road noise with a lot of motorcyclist revving up and down the main strip.

Cons:

Dated, very dated. The room could use a lot of freshening up (new paint would be a good start as the walls are marked up a lot).

The two arm chairs are not comfortable (hard)

The mattress and pillows are very, very hard. Mattress is thin. (Hard is kind of a theme here).

Shower: while the water temp was good, the pressure was anemic.

Overall, for two nights it was fine. Unfortunately during this pandemic time, we could not partake in their breakfast (they did provide a 'bag' breakfast with your choice of prepackaged pastry, a small carton of juice and a breakfast bar - the bare necessities). And daily housekeeping was not provided unless by request.
place: Helendorf River Inn and Conference Center

title: Best Donuts Anywhere and the Breakfast is good
text: I love donuts and specifically chocolate covered donuts. Hofer's has the very best donuts I've ever had. My only regret is I didn't buy more. Now my wife would say that the apple fritters are better and got to admit they were very good (she was kind enough to share part of hers). And while I'm on it, the cinnamon twist donut was fresh and delicious. So got to say, you can't miss on this place to fulfill your donut and pastry needs. We also ate breakfast here (go early, the line gets long just after opening). I enjoyed their Belgium waffle with a side of ham. Wife had their French toast. Both were outstanding.

title: Worth Trying
text: After eating at another popular restaurant in Helen, we decided to try out Old Heidelberg one night and were glad we did. Arriving just before 7pm, we were promptly seated inside and the wait staff was very attentive (to the point they turned the fan off above us as it was a bit too much for our liking). The food here is a hit. We ordered the Wurst sampler (three sausages) with a double order of sauerkraut; a large pretzel; and a bowl of their Goulash soup. The three wurst were grilled perfectly, not overcooked. The sauerkraut was on the better side with bits of ham and on the mild side, but not too mild. We asked the they not put the herb butter on our pretzel which I believe made it more akin to what you get in Germany and was nicely done. Goulash was a hit with my wife with large chunks of meat and the broth was very tasty. Even had spazi. This will be our go to restaurant for dinner when we're next in the area.

title: Great setting, Good food
text: Took advantage of their early bird specials and glad we did to beat the crowds. Overlooking the bay, the scenery is what you would expect and want in a Florida restaurant. For dinner, we ordered the Sea Bass Fish and Chips for me and the coconut shrimp for my wife. The fish and chips were ok. Portion was large. Fish was a bit too 'fishy' for me (would prefer cod). Coconut shrimp was excellent (also a large portion). Did order the shrimp cocktail and it was loaded with medium size shrimp. Bread was served upon request. Service was very attentive.

title: That "Florida" Feel
text: A perfect day for outdoor sitting topped off with good food and killer dessert. Our first visit and the lunch fare was very good. Two of us had their classic burgers with fries. The burgers were hand patted, cooked to order and the pickles tasted like homemade. Great taste and large. Fries were great. Our party also ordered the BLFGT their signature sandwich. It was good, not great. The fried green tomato could have been left in the fryer for a bit more. Also had the southwest chicken wrap which was good, though messy (dripping sauces and ended up just unwrapping and eating. It's on the spicy side so beware. For dessert we had two of their specialty sundaes (one caramel, one brownie) and a separate bowl of ice cream. Excellent and way over the top.

title: Good, Nothing Special
text: Was ready for a great ice cream treat, but alas, it appears to be just another ice cream shoppe (albeit no a lot of competition on the island) that serves ready made (not homemade). Adult size scoop is large and kid size while a bit smaller, would suffice for most people. Mint chocolate chip had a slight chalky aftertaste (probably due to the brand they use).

title: It's A Subway, enough said
text:
After turning back from our first dinner choice due to large crowds and no social distancing, we stopped in at this Subway to grab a sandwich for dinner. Lo and behold, no bread. Did have wraps and pita and since we were a bit hungry, we ordered a couple of pita sandwiches. Apparently Subway has reduced its menu eliminating some of my favorites but we managed to get a couple of good sandwiches anyway.

As a last resort, this was fine.

title: Great Pizza
text:
Order take out (large pepperoni and a large ham, sausage, beef) for our family of six and all I can say is it was great. Plenty of cheese and toppings.

Order was ready when we got there (15 minutes from time of order to time of pick up).

Indoors looked like plenty of space to dine in.

title: A Hidden Gem in a sea of seafood restaurants
text:
When you've had your fill of seafood, try this hidden gem serving excellent Italian fare. The menu is limited but there's something for everyone. The portions are large and the staff is friendly. Right now the hours are also limited so good to call ahead especially during times of high influx of tourists (like us).

Our order consisted of Chicken Alfredo (for wife) and their Spaghetti with Meatball (large meatball). The entrees came with a house salad (leafy greens, tomatoes, cucumbers, cranberries (nice and plump) and walnuts. You can ask them to hold any of the adds if you don't like them. Bread (baguette ) is served as well.

The Alfredo was excellent with its wide egg noodles cooked al dente. The spaghetti with it's home-made red sauce was also delicious.

Skipped dessert as we were stuffed. Take note, they have apparently just moved into a new and larger facility on US 98 so you may need to call for directions if your GPS takes you to an almost empty strip mall.

title: Go on a Monday, Get the Fried Chicken
text: Want good fried chicken - go on a Monday. You won't be disappointed if you like chicken like your momma made. Had half a chicken (leg, wing, thigh and breast) all fried to perfection with a slightly seasoned covering. Yum. Ate them all. Fries and rice are my sides but didn't eat many of the fries as I was stuffed from the chicken Didn't touch the rice. Had their fried pickles as an appetizer. They are addictive and enough to share with an entire table. Wife had their fish tacos and she rated them very good. Go for the food, but the staff is equally nice.

title: Average but perhaps it's what we ordered
text: Didn't go for the BBQ (which may be what sets this apart). Dropped in for lunch and service was good and friendly. Had their fried shrimp basket with fries. The shrimp (six) were large enough, nicely breaded and the cocktail sauce had a nice bite to it. Fries were a disappointment (had a bit of a fishy taste, guess they use the same oil). Wife had their chicken sandwich (grilled) and it was good enough.

title: High Expectations. So So Donuts
text: Oh how I wish the donuts lived up to all the hype I heard. Are they good? Yes. Are they great? Well not really, but they are good. These are cake donuts where one size fits all with difference being the toppings. No novelty donuts like bear claws or twists and certainly not the Krispy Kreme style. Line gets long (were were there just after opening and line was around the front of the fronting building. So yes, get there early and expect to wait. Cash only.

title: Worthy of Lunch
text:
Asked a local for a recommendation for lunch and this was not it (in fact was told it was overpriced and they add a surcharge due to the pandemic). But after looking at several other places, we at here anyway. It was better than expected and given prices in this touristy area, didn't find it overpriced. Plus didn't see a surcharge our bill.

The order: Wife had the fish sandwich lunch special (grilled, you can get fried or blackened) with potato salad and fries. The fish (grouper I believe) was a nice size, fried well on a bun and was very tasty. Topped only by the potato salad which she rated as excellent (and she knows here potato salad). Fries were better than other places we've eaten in lately so all told this was a winner at $12.99

My order was the fried shrimp basket with fries. After sending it back once, they brought me fish, not shrimp, all was well. Basked was a dozen large (and I'm talking big, fat and juicy) lightly breaded and lightly fried shrimp. Fantastic. Again with fries but to be honest, couldn't eat all the fries or even half. Price $14.99

Dessert: piece of key lime for me (just so so and rather skinny slice) and a piece of coconut pie for my wife, which she rated very good.

Two soft drinks.

All orders were taken at the counter. No table service (they call your number, you pick it up in disposable containers). Social distancing in effect and mask usage is a bit skimpy.

title: Great Food with the convenience of delivery
text: As we are under a stay in place order and couldn't go out for an anniversary dinner, we took this occasion to order from Stevarinos and take advantage of their delivery service. Glad we did. While not the overly romantic dinner we envisioned, the food was every bit as good as the reviews we read. Order consisted of the Monterey Chicken with potatoes and pasta salad (excellent) and a medium Dublin Pizza (also excellent). Were surprised that a mini-loaf of bread was included. The pizza was enough for two meals and the meats were piled high (almost too high). Crust was wonderful. Am looking forward to trying their more traditional Italian fare next time and perhaps their steaks.

title: Avoid if you can
text: One of the worst carriers we've been on. Our first time with them and hopefully will be our last. Only took as they are partners with Delta. Plane was dirty, old and needed a lot of refreshing. Food was minimal. Check in was ok.

title: New Upscaled Dining in Economy a fail
text:
First experience with the upgraded economy class dining on some of their international routes and honestly there are some nice touches (menu and disposable place mats) but in the end it's all about the food and it remains as inedible as before. The choices are as expected limited. They did offer a complimentary drink which I guess some people liked. We were in row 31 and by the time they got to us, they were out of the shrimp appetizer (as the attendant said, they run out of those by the sixth row - well perhaps they should learn something and plan for more). The entrees were terrible and even the roll was hard. Best think was the ice cream. So good try Delta, but still a long way to go. Will continue to bring my snacks in fear of starving.

Seats were pretty good. Entertainment was good. Bathrooms were filthy (not Delta's fault but passengers are just pigs when they get in the air - would be nice if Delta cleaned them occasionally though). One of the attendants was a hoot and engaged the passengers. Others were just there to do their job. Typical.

title: Our First Experience
text: Overall had a very good experience flying Aegean for the first time. Check in was relatively easy though a bit confusing as the instructions at the check-in kiosk indicated I first had to pay for bags then come back and check in. The ticket agent took care of taking both my money for the checked bag and the overall check in. The boarding area was a bit crowded and hard to hear the announcements but we followed the crowd. A bit surprised that they boarded (for economy class) the window and middle seats before the aisle seats. Hadn't seen that in any other airline we've flown. No big deal other than the little added stress of no overhead room for your carry-on. Service was good and no issues there. Would fly them again should we be in the area.

title: So Interesting
text: A little hard to find, but if you happen to be strolling the back streets or Chania Old Town and come across this Synagogue, it's worth the time to knock and visit the interior. The docents are very friendly and informative. The small museum has some very interesting artifacts and the synagogue has an interesting history.

title: Reliable and Reasonable Transportation
text: We used this service for pickup and drop-off from Chania airport to our hotel and very satisfied with the service. Cars were clean and newer model Mercedes. The drivers were friendly. Would use them again.

title: Little Gem
text: After spending the prior week on the mainland going from museum to museum, was surprised how nice this one was. No hordes of visitors so you have time to spend at each exhibit. The display of ancient coins was particularly interesting.

title: Great Exhibits
text: An excellent little museum with displays showcasing the maritime history of Crete. Some very interesting WWII showcases. Spend a little time in the courtyard outside.

title: Further than you think
text: It's a bit of a walk to get to the lighthouse and you'll need to navigate a little rock field about two-thirds there. Offers some nice views back towards the harbor. Not much to it other than for pictures (can't go in) but those are worth the effort to get there.

title: When You Need Something Familiar
text: After a week traveling around Greece and enjoying big meals everywhere, stopped in at this Pizza Hut just up the street from our hotel for a little bit of the familiar. Ordered a mushroom and cheese large pizza with two soft drinks. Not a lot of people in the place but it looks like it does a good delivery service. No frills but the pizza was good.

title: Great Lunch with Views
text: For lunch, you can find no better views to join with a great lunch. We were seated in the main room at the large windows overlooking the valley. For mains we had the chicken filet which was very good, the chicken pasta (excellent) and a couple baskets of their wonderful bread. Of course fresh orange juice. Total was a very reasonable 25 euros. Service was top notched. The portions were large.

title: All about the view
text: Situated above the town of Delphi, the views from this hotel are to die for. The hotel itself is nice and caters to tours (such as ours). The road to the hotel is windy and just hope you don't run into a bus. Our room on the third floor was nice and clean. Had good heat both in the room and in the bathroom (a rarity on our trip). The shower unfortunately is a bit awkward with the hand held shower but that's typical of these older hotels that adapt a hand held shower to what was just a bathtub. The bed was good (not too hard) but the pillows were rock hard. The breakfast buffet was limited and was so disappointed with the orange juice (from concentrate and weak, after having fresh in most hotels and all restaurants it was a let down). The hotel offered a welcome drink (non-alcoholic cherry drink) which was refreshing and sweet. We had a set menu dinner in the hotel which was good, not great.

title: It's Not all About the Views
text: The views are undoubtedly fantastic, but there's so much more to this hotel than that. The rooms are wonderful and not your usual hotel room. Ours was located on the same floor as reception and were quite surprised when we entered and saw the layout included a sunken seating area along with a wonderful balcony overlooking the pool. The decor is modern. Bathroom was large and has an interesting window between it and the bedroom (not to worry has a shade that can be drawn). The bed was comfortable with plenty of pillows. The sitting area had a nice two person couch, table and solo seat. On the down side, the design is not conducive to heating the place due to it's split level. Very quiet location but not convenient to town. The buffet breakfast was standard though we had a good meal in the hotel restaurant. Wonderful shower (one of the best we had on our tour) though not a fan of the half glass enclosure. Super clean. Walls are a bit thin.

title: Best in the Area
text: Our tour group stayed nearby and this was one of the few restaurant options available in the area from what we could see. So we ate here twice and both times were pleased with the food and the price. For our first dinner, our mains included the grill plate for one (very good and plenty of food, couple pieces of grilled chicken, half a sausage, hamburger (minced meat, not a fan), pork chop and bacon) plus fries of course, and the chicken schnitzel with cheese. The cheese on the schnitzel overwhelmed the dish and ended up having to scrape it off. The bread was fresh and hot. With a soft drink (water was gratis), the total was a very reasonable 23 euros. For out second trip, we went with plain chicken schnitzel and grilled chicken, both with fries and break and a very good lemonade. Price was just about 20 euros. Would definitely eat here again.

title: A nice place to try
text: Stumbled onto this place as we looked for a place to eat on our first night in Athens. The 'catcher' was personable so while there were not many eating at the time (we eat early by Greek standards) we got a table inside. Overall the food was good though not great. For mains I had the grilled shrimp (five prawns, a bit on the chewy side and as the waiter told me when asked if they were fresh, " they were frozen fresh, just like fresh". Thought that was a funny way to put it). Wife had the chicken souvlaki which was very good. With a side of garlic bread, the bill with a small tip was 35 euros. About average for what we paid per meal.

title: When in Athens, Eat Ice Cream
text: And this is the place to enjoy some really good ice cream. Stopped in twice for their Belgium chocolate ice cream (rich, dark chocolate) and a bubble cone (bubble waffle that was sweet though a bit messy to eat). Mixed in a bit of vanilla one time and lemon another. Yum. The hot chocolate is like sipping a cup of chocolate pudding. Saw other Kayak stores in various stages of readiness around Greece, but none were open (boo).

title: The Crown Jewell in Athens
text: Can't miss this place. It's more than just the Parthenon. Go early, wear hiking shoes or something with a grabby sole. Can be very slippery if any moisture on the pathway (that marble is slick).

title: "THE" Site to see
text: Went in off season and had the place virtually to ourselves A bit of a walk up, but plenty of places to stop along the way to take in the various ruins. Views from the top do not disappoint and the Parthenon itself is a sight to behold.

title: A must stop
text: This is a first class museum. The exhibits are well planned and movement between areas facilitates large crowds. Pictures are allowed except in one area. If you are on a group ticket, don't go into the cafeteria area as you may get asked to see a ticket when you leave. Good museum shop on first floor. Skip the book store on the cafeteria floor (not much there and overpriced).

title: If only the Grandeous of the Lobby extended to Rooms
text: First impressions upon entering the hotel were wonderful. The Lobby is grand and promises a five star property. Check in was efficient and staff were welcoming. Unfortunately that grandeur didn't extend to the room. Our room (512) was booked as an Executive Special. While it did overlook the pool, the direct view out of the window was of back of a structure which I believe houses the rooftop restaurant. Virtually no view of anything of interest. The room included 1 king size bed, a small refrigerator, a good size bathroom though no heat (or air) and was cold, the hand-held shower was awkwardly placed and you got very familiar with the cord (obviously a retrofit and would have been better if they had just replumbed the shower stall). The bathroom was very clean, no sign of mold. The old phone in the bedroom was dirty. Room lacked plugs and no USB ports. Lighting is poor though typical of most hotel rooms we encountered in Greece. On the plus side, the breakfast was really good though would be nice if it opened before 7am. The views from the breakfast area were great. Location to attractions was very good. Being on the backside of the hotel, it did make for a more quiet stay. Check out was smooth and they held our luggage while we spent additional time exploring the area before departing. Also made sure our taxi driver knew exactly where we were heading.

title: The Food is Great, The Staff Greater
text: This became our go to place when we were on tour in Athens a couple of weeks ago. We 'ran into' Irene on our first night and she was all smiles. We ended up however at another place (our mistake) but the next day as we strolled the area, we saw Irene and immediately knew we had to eat at Elaea at least once. We ended up having three meals there over the next two days and each one was great. Each time we were greeted with smiles and a friendly chat with the host, seated promptly and was attended to by the entire staff as old friends. The food was wonderful (I still miss the spaghetti) and the prices reasonable. If we're ever back in Athens, this will be the first place we stop by.

title: THE place to stay in Chania
text: As charming as Chania is, La Maison Ottomane is the jewel atop the crown. Alex was the perfect host and the room was comfortable and well appointed. We enjoyed sitting out on the balcony with a nice view of the sea, peeling and enjoying the fantastic oranges (mentioned to Alex how much I liked the oranges and next thing I know we have a bowl full to enjoy). The waterfall shower was fantastic. I'm not a huge breakfast type, but the french toast was wonderful (and have I mentioned the fresh orange juice?) Location wise, it's a easy walk to the sea front in the old town and being less than 2 tenths of a mile from the harbor meant a much quieter night and better sleep. If our travels brings us back to Chania, this will be the only place we stay.

title: Better than the reviews.
text: Passed by this place a half dozen times during our stay and the ‘catcher’ was always pleasant and not pushy so we stopped in for our last Chania meal and chatted with him as he remembered us from our passings. We eat early so were the only ones on the place. Found it to be very friendly. Started with a complimentary bowl of soup. I don’t eat soup other than chicken noodle but this beef based one was very tasty. I had the spaghetti Napolitan which was good, not great. Wife had mousaki which she enjoyed. A basket of toasted bread and a large orange juice (great) and with the small service fee added the total was 24.8 euros. Place is definitely better than the ratings I later saw on TA. The complimentary dish of what I think was custard was yummy.

title: Hard to find but worth it
text:
We stumbled upon this small taverna in the back alley of the old town and at first passed it up. Decided next day to come back and eat and glad we did.

Place is small. 14 seats indoors and a few tables outside. Menu is not as extensive as other places and the name of the game is fresh fish. We both had the grilled dorado which comes with a little green side (looked like rocket salad). They kind of pushed into a small Greek salad to split. Wife is glad they did as it had the best cheese on top. Lots of tomatoes and cucumbers. Plenty for two. Also an order of bread. The fish was great! No tap water offered so bottle water. With a glass of fresh orange juice the total bill was 44.5 euros. Most expensive meal we had in Crete and Greece. While there a guy dropped off a few more fish I presume for the folks coming later. The familiar complementary orange cake and drink were offered.

title: More than just a track
text: Sure you can snap pictures from beyond the fence but pay the small entrance fee to walk or run around, sit on the marble seats and go through the tunnel to see some of the past Olympic memorabilia

title: Better Places. Keep Looking
text:
Had dinner and at best would say it was below average. Appearance wise it is in dire need of a refreshing. A coat of paint on the inside would do a world of charm. It does not look like the picture on TA (maybe years ago when it first opened). But on to the food.

We started off with some water and a non carbonated soft drink which the waiter knocked over spilling a good third of it on my wife. Accidents happen but did he bother to replace the drink? Nope. The small shrimp fried appetizer was good and plenty for a table. Bread was ok though no dips just a small bottle of olive oil (though there was a large one on the table). French fries were good. For mains we ordered the chicken fillet. Worse we have had while traveling Greece. No flavor at all. It was large though. I ordered shrimp spaghetti in spicy tomato sauce. No spice other than garlic. Had plenty of shrimp but again just bland.

Wait staff were pretty non interested in us (beyond the normal European we won’t interrupt your meal approach which we appreciate). Total for this bland experience was 29 euros.

title: Revisited after many years and glad we did
text:
Although I've lived in the Chattanooga area for over 40 years, it's been at least 15 years since last visited Ruby Falls. Now that our grandkids were old enough to enjoy (and looking for something to do over their Christmas break), we took them for their first tour of the falls and to their Underground Christmas tour. First tip - reserve your tickets on line before you arrive in Chattanooga and go as early in the morning after opening as you can to avoid the big crowds. Added bonus is that if for some reason the falls are closed (the cave flooded on the day of our visited closing the normal route for half a day, though the Christmas experience was open) you'll get an email and options (call their customer service line for better service). I ended up cancelling the normal tour, keeping the Christmas experience. Though when we got to the Falls, used their booking kiosk to rebook tickets for the normal cave tour as they reopened just before noon (saved standing in line to buy tickets, and you can select your timed entry tickets).

From the eyes of our grands, this was a total success. If you're lucky to visit during a rainy day or after, the volume of water from the falls is great. The light show is a bit tacky but the mist is real and smiles all around. The Underground Christmas experience was child friendly fun. A wonderful Santa awaits kids and grownups alike. Plus you get a souvenir geode to take home.

Much improved from the days of yore when I first visited. Yes, there are lines and can be crowded, though as a tourist destination, it's not a 'trap' and doesn't pretend to be anything other than good family fun. Hard core spelunkers have other options in Chattanooga.

title: Way better than King Salmon
text: After eating at King Salmon, Canyon Steakhouse was a welcomed relief for our second night's dinner. It's located just outside the Princess lodge area easily accessible by free transport. We were famished having been on a full day excursion into the park and were happy to have been seated within 5 minutes of arriving. Our waitress was friendly and engaging. So much different than our previous experience at the Lodge. This is a beef place so we ordered the Porterhouse ($42) and the Beef Tenderloin ($34). Both were cooked as ordered. The sides were very good and the bread was fresh. The Porterhouse was enough for two (a full pound) which I devoured. No dessert this night but am sure it would have been as good as the mains.
placeLocation: Denali National Park and Preserve, Alaska

title: Our first smasburger experience
text: Not bad for a burger joint in an airport. The classic burger (two), fries (one order shared) and soda ($CD27.40) was tasty and fresh. So no problems there. Not a lot of options for dining at the airport that we could find so can't compare it to others.

title: Be sure to have a reservation
text: Not knowing what to expect at the lodge, we snagged a reservation here for our first night dinner. It is the up-price (not necessary upscale) restaurant on property and gets extremely busy. After being seated, we waited a bit before for our waiter and then longer for some bread. We ordered the Grilled Alaskan Salmon plate and the Asiago Crusted Halibut without the Asiago crust and a side of fries. The grilled salmon was very good and a nice portion. The halibut was on the small side and was ok, not great (expected great being Alaska). Fries were good. Waiter was inattentive for the most part. My glass of water was long gone and I flagged down another wait person for a refill after giving up on him. For dessert ordered the Apple Crisp expecting something great (like the one I had at the Grand Canyon) but alas, it was pretty lame. Again small and not a lot of apple or crisp. Overall the priciest dinner we had on our trip ($73 for the two mains and dessert, plus a smaller tip than what I usual leave). Better places around than this.
placeLocation: Denali National Park and Preserve, Alaska

title: Kantishna Experience
text: Definitely the tour to take. Full day (11+ hours on the bus with a few stops to stretch legs, restrooms and snap pictures.). Narrator was excellent and they utilize a neat binocular/camera system that plays on the in-bus monitors for close ups on spotted wildlife. You go to 'the end of the road' on this one and back. We hit it on a cloudless day so Denali was in all of it's glory and splendor. Was late in the season so the big herds were gone, but saw the big 5 and multiples. The box lunch provided was adequate (apple, wrap sandwich, orange juice) but would suggest taking some of your own munchies. Water was also provided. Sit on the left side (driver side) if you can on the way out.
placeLocation: Denali National Park and Preserve, Alaska

title: Buffet Breakfast was OK
text: Stopped in for their buffet breakfast prior to an early start excursion as it was one of the earliest places opened. Overall the buffet was adequate though the selection was a bit limited in my opinion. Had a small selection of cereals (not individually packaged), steel cut oats (were good), scrambled eggs (a bit too runny for me), some breads, yogurt, half way decent bacon, the required reindeer sausage and a few other times. Had a fairly good hot chocolate, orange juice and coffee. Price was $18.99 per person plus tip . Wait staff was friendly enough for the early hour. Place was a bit cold. Overall better than the snack bar at the lodge, though it could have been better.
placeLocation: Denali National Park and Preserve, Alaska

title: Thank Goodness for the Scenery
text: We stayed here overnight on a Princess land/cruise vacation with a room in Building 19. The resort is fairly remote so unless you travel to Talkeenta about an hour away ($10 per person round trip) you're resort bound. The main lodge is the hub of activity with an overpriced gift shop but plenty of places to sit around and very nice deck area with views of the majestic Denali. The lodge also has a coffee shop for quick bite breakfast (get there early as they sell out of the best stuff quickly), an upscale dining area (pricey but good, dress in whatever you want) and a less formal dining option that's pretty crowded. There's another stand alone eatery close by with outdoor fire pits (music at night). The lodge rooms are large with a large bathroom. Good shower. Lousy TV reception. No wifi outside of the main lodge. Several easy hiking paths along the perimeter of the property with a nice short walk to the Treehouse for more great views.

title: Quirky and Fun Place
text: Friends recommended this place for both food and ambiance. Stopped in for a late (almost too late breakfast - served until 3pm). Sitting is communal at large tables. Just find an open seat and the menu is on the table (along with all add ons you'll need with your meal). Tip: push by those lining up at the bakery cases to get to the dining room. For breakfast I ordered the pancake (half, was going for full but waitress cautioned against that - glad she did). Wife ordered breakfast with eggs, bacon (peppered bacon was great), some hash browns and got a whole plate with enough to feed two it looks like. Also got choice of beverage (coffee for her, hot chocolate for me) and a choice of juice. Their signature pancakes overflow a standard size dinner plate (sourdough batter). Great cakes. Nice place to hang out. It does close early so don't lose haste. Total for two (no tipping allowed) was $34.20

title: Table with a view
text:
The upscale dining option at the resort and the prices reflect that. We lucked out and got a table next to the windows with a view of Denali at sunset. Can be a little hectic at the front desk with a lot of folks milling around trying to snag reservations (which are a must unless you want to wait and dine much later). We waited about 20 minutes past our reservation time to be seated which was fine as where else are you going to go?

Our order: Chicken Pot Pie ($23) for the wife, Ribeye for me. The Chicken Pot Pie was large and while I thought the sauce was not as good as Stouffer's or Boston Market, wife though it was tasty as well as a good crust. The Ribeye ($41) was a bit on the slim side (thinner cut than one would expect) but was cooked to right temperature (medium rare). Good taste and they readily substituted a side of fries instead the mash potatoes. No dessert, no room. Server did a great job.
